When I was 15 I took LSD for the first time not fully comprehending the implications of doing so. About an hour and a half later I still felt nothing and asked my friend for another hit of gel tabs, we went back to his home I started to feel a little strange but I had been high on marijuana before nothing really that out of the ordinary. We went to my so-called friends older sister's room at his parents house and he asked his sister for some marijuana to smoke, She also asked if we wanted some of that dust I did not know at the time that dust meant PCP. I wound up in a demonic dimension we're humans were golf balls on a rotating conveyor belt that dropped us onto a driving green. When it was my turn to be dropped from this machine I noticed that I was hundreds of feet high, I could feel the wind and I could hear the Roar of 2 horrible-looking Giants in late 1800 Scottish golf attire laughing at us. When I dropped I felt the G-Force like going straight down on a roller coaster and landed on the driving green. The red-haired giant which was approximately 500 or so feet tall looked at the dark-haired one laughed and drove me across a large Lake and I landed on an island green where I went into the hole for a hole-in-one. I then found myself in my friends kitchen where he turned into a demon in front of my eyes with green slime and sharp teeth his ears grew in his eyes turned yellow, also the dog in the room that was in a cage turn to a demon as well every time the Rottweiler barked it grew and grew and started to fill the entire room. I broke through his sliding glass window and ran down the street he said faster than he'd ever seen anybody run in his life. While I ran I noticed that everything was getting darker, none of the houses had color anymore the trees were not green and The Lawns were not green anymore but everything turned Grey, then darker and darker. Then all of the sudden the lights turned out completely. I did not know at the time but I was in the place where the Bible speaks of the outer Darkness where there is weeping and gnashing of teeth. Unbeknownst to me fully at the time I was hit by a car and the EMS drivers picked me up in the ditch about a mile from my buddies house. My soul kept trying to return to my body and when it did I was inside an ambulance and they were asking me what I took and what happened and that I had been hit by a car. I remember my blood pressure being 210 / 180. Then all the sudden like a snap of a finger I was back in absolute utter Terror darkness and the only light was a light above my head with the perimeter around me up about 10 or so feet. I could see the Silhouettes and the eyes of the demons in the outer Darkness that could not penetrate the light but I understood their language and they were telling me they were going to rip me apart and laughed because I did not know Jesus Christ as my Lord and Savior. All of the sudden the light started to fade from around me and the perimeter got closer and closer to my body to the point where one of the Demons was able to get his claws upon my flesh and I could feel his hair he was a massive Beast. But because there was just a small amount of light it was like being on novocaine at the dentist you could feel pressure but no real pain. It was utter hopelessness and Terror indescribable. When you are in the Darkness you know the truth about everything nothing is hidden you have the mind of Christ and you understand where you are, why you're there and that you will never be able to leave for all eternity you are stuck there in torment. As the light was almost gone I remember falling to my knees and at this point the demons had me in Chains when I called out to the Lord Jesus Christ for the first time in my life truly. Then all the sudden the chains begin to break one by one. I got to the point I could get my legs out and start running towards this light and it was a light like I've never seen brighter any light here in this world. I broke the chains and like a flash of lightning I wound up in an orb on a floating what looked to be operating table. To the right of me was the most beautiful woman I had ever seen and the only explanation was she was an angel. Her hair was gold and literally sang songs as she floated over to my bedside, she did not speak from her mouth but from her heart and she touched my shoulder very gently and said"We have you now you are going to be just fine." The orb that I was in was approximately 15 feet wide by 8 feet tall. There was also a man on board, he was an African-American looking man very strong he did not say a word and as soon as I saw him I wept because every time I heard a racist song or friends said the n-word it came flooding back to my mind and I was truly convicted. He was looking up at like a screen and he was touching it like a touchscreen directing this orb. She looked at him in almost disbelief and said in the most gentle voice I've ever heard,"I can't believe we were actually able to save this one because he was so far gone!"Then she took large needle-like Rod's that were rainbows and stuck them into both of my arms, at this time I could feel the force of gravity lifting us up at an accelerating rate. As we were accelerating up instead of blood total darkness came out of me blacker than any black I've ever seen floating like when you see astronauts in so-called outer space all around the cabin of the orb. I understood that blood is the life and in the outer Darkness you do not have blood and you literally become the darkness. After all of the tar like blood came out of me like a flash the orb disappears and I'm flying in a rainbow tunnel of light, next thing I know I'm in the emergency room, they had cleared the entire right side of the floor and had a team surrounding me. I was in spirit form hovering looking down at me but not realizing that I wasn't in my body. I remember I had defecated on myself and a pretty young nurse was tasked to undress me and I was yelling at her but she couldn't hear me when I told her that "I'm okay look I'm right here I'm fine!" I remember looking into the pupils of my eyes and I did not blink I remember how dilated they were that they had to put solution in my eyes every so often. I was able to look around the room across to the other rooms but I still didn't know I wasn't in my body so I was getting upset. I thought I was fine. All the sudden there were these men dressed in what I thought were potato bags but I now know is sack cloth robes with hoods. These men circled my bed with their arms crossed over their heart they began to what I can only assume was a prayer to put me back into my physical body. The next day I was in the recovery room and had EKG leads and IV tubes all over my body. And for about five seconds I knew all the secrets of the universe I remember getting out of bed and shouting to call our local newspaper because I have so much to say about everything in this world and the afterlife. But after just a Split Second all but a few memories vanished from my mind. I was drawn to the door and a little boy stopped at my door turned to me and without moving his lips like the angel in the orb told me this was my second chance. He smiled with a twinkle in his eye began to walk down the hallway once again. I wanted to thank him so I ripped my IVs and EKG leads off and was at the door in 3 seconds and the young boy was gone! I have never told this story on any social media platform before and some people might say it was just a bad trip. But I believe LSD and other hallucinogens open up doorways to demonic portals that may never be shut if you go so far down that rabbit hole like I was. I want no one not even my worst enemy to experience that level of Torment. Jesus Christ is the Way, he is the Truth and he is the Life, and no man or woman comes to the father without knowing Jesus Christ as their lord and savior. Please accept Jesus Christ as your lord and savior before it's too late! Brothers and sisters we are not promised or guaranteed one more second on this Earth, do you know where you will go when you die? I have heard of fire and brimstone and I'm sure there's such places but to be in utter darkness and despair with demons is unimaginable. I will share one of the truths I was able to take back with me, when a child dies in this world albeit tragically, untimely or by abortion those children become Warrior angels for the Kingdom of Heaven. In my open vision while I was in the Darkness I was standing at the precipice of a large pit with smoke coming out of it. Behind me was a red sky with mountains all around this crevasse. All the sudden the earth started to tremble around me and over the mountains there were what appeared to be shock waves that were sound coming down the mountain over me and down into the pit. As the sound grew louder I could hear the voices singing our God is an awesome God! After a period of time as the sound grew and grew I saw what appeared to be countless legions of children that were armored not unlike Spartan gladiators with wings and I knew that these children had perished early and they're being used as an Unstoppable Force against the enemy! 4 friends, 17 year old Julie, 18 year old Amy, 16 year old Jasmine and 15 year old Cora all find out they are pregnant at the same time.
Despite the initial shock, the decision of what to do was a no brainer for Amy. She wanted to keep her baby. She'd be finished school by the time it was born anyway and it wouldn't stop her from attending college, becuase she knew that both her parents were pro life, like her and wouldn't want her to abort it. She also knew that her parents would help her take care of it, and she would be able to leave the baby with them when she was at college.
Jasmine, however thought differently. She couldn't keep this baby, she would have to abort it. Her reason for doing this was that she was afraid her parents would disown her or physically hurt it if they found out. She didn't have anywhere else to go if they kicked her out. And if they physically hurt her, they'd probably kill the baby anyway since it was so small (8 weeks gestation).
17 year old Julie and 15 year old Cora both came to the decision that they would keep their pregnancies, but not the babies. They would give life to them and then put them up for adoption.
When all the girls were 22 weeks pregnant they were out on a road trip. Julie got out of the car to use the bathroom at a gas station. Whilst the other three girls were waiting in the car, something terrible happened. A van crashed into the back of their car. Tragically, the airbag pressed right up against Amy's stomach, causing the placenta to disconnect. Her baby did not make it.
Jasmine hurt her stomach becuase of the airbag too, but there was no baby in there anymore, so no life was lost. She was alright.
Unfortunately tho, Cora was in the back seat and the airbags were broken, so no airbag protected her and the roof of the car caved in and hit her head. A bit of it bounced of her head and onto her stomach, Her baby went into distress.
When the girls got to the hospital, Amy already pretty much knew that her baby hadn't survived, and this was confirmed. Julie had followed Cora into her room in A and E. Out of the blue they asked her how far along Cora was. Julie asked "why?" They said "Her baby is in distress, if it's at the age of viability, we need to deliver it now otherwise it will die. But if she hasn't hit the age of viability, We don't need to do anything" Julie stared at the ultrasound as she could see the heart beat and the baby moving around. She told a white lie and said "Well, Let me think. She's a week and a half ahead of me, she's 23 weeks, almost 24." They believed her and saved the baby. Amy, Jasmine and Julie went to see the baby 5 hours later. Amy was in bits that she'd lost her baby. Jasmine however, was seemingly coping well, until she saw Cora's baby. She listened as Julie explained how she'd told a white lie about how far along Cora was to make them save the baby, how she'd saw the baby move on the scan. Then she made the comment, "I can't believe I had to lie to have them save it, it's clearly a baby and it's alive and somewhat well now. And to think, there is no biological difference between this baby and the one inside me. Babies the same gestational age as Cora's can legally be aborted even though they have the potential to survive, like hers if born." That was the last straw for Jasmine. She left the room in tears. All she could think was "There would be no biological difference between that baby and mine, if mine was still here. But it's not. Why did I do this???" Unfortunately tho, it was too late for Jasmine. Her reason for having an abortion was understandable of course, but now she regretted it. And there was now nothing to do but continue to regret it, forever.
Cora ended up changing her mind about adoption, she decided she wanted to keep it with her family once she saw the baby, 3 weeks after it was born. She was able to find out it was a girl and she had that chance of changing her mind. A choice that Jasmine never got becuase she had an abortion.
Julie stuck with her decision to give the baby up for adoption when it was born 18 weeks later. But she was still able to find out the gender, it was a boy. This was another choice Jasmine never got. She will never know what gender her baby would have been had it been able to develop enough to have one. She could only guess.
Amy had a rainbow baby 6 years later. (Which just so happen to also be when Cora moved out of home with her now 6 year old daughter.) Even though this was an option that was open for Jasmime, she felt she didn't deserve another child because she'd chosen to have her first child aborted. When she was in her late 20s, She decided to foster, so that she could help as many kids as possible, to make it up to herself for doing what she did.
Wow, thank you for reading all that. As you probably guessed, this is a hypothetical scenario, it is not based of real people, but the situations of each girl and sometimes, the situation all 4 of them ended up in do happen to people everyday.

“I accepted an invitation to talk to the women's branch of the Ku Klux Klan... I was escorted to the platform, was introduced, and began to speak...In the end, through simple illustrations I believed I had accomplished my purpose. A dozen invitations to speak to similar groups were proffered.”
-- Margaret Sanger, An Autobiography, published in 1938

“The most serious evil of our times is that of encouraging the bringing into the world of large families. The most immoral practice of the day is breeding too many children..."
-- Sanger, Margaret. Woman and the New Race (1920). Chapter 5: The Wickedness of Creating Large Families. 

"No woman shall have the legal right to bear a child, and no man shall have the right to become a father, without a permit for parenthood."
-- Margaret Sanger, "America Needs a Code for Babies," Article 4, March 27, 1934.

"Permits for parenthood shall be issued upon application by city, county, or state authorities to married couples, providing they are financially able to support the expected child, have the qualifications needed for proper rearing of the child, have no transmissible diseases, and, on the woman’s part, no medical indication that maternity is likely to result in death or permanent injury to health."
-- Margaret Sanger, "America Needs a Code for Babies," Article 5, March 27, 1934.

“We should hire three or four colored ministers, preferably with social-service backgrounds, and with engaging personalities. The most successful educational approach to the Negro is through a religious appeal. We don’t want the word to go out that we want to exterminate the Negro population. And the minister is the man who can straighten out that idea if it ever occurs to any of their more rebellious members.”

– Margaret Sanger’s December 19, 1939 letter to Dr. Clarence Gamble, 255 Adams Street, Milton, Massachusetts. Original source: Sophia Smith Collection, Smith College, North Hampton, Massachusetts. So if a fetus is not a person, what is it? Fetuses are alive, no one can deny that. They’re obviously not plants, insects, or bacteria, so the only possibility left is that fetuses are animals.

So, let’s pretend a fetus is a non-human animal. Now that it’s settled, allow me use an example to demonstrate why killing a non-human animal in a similar fashion as one used in a human abortion is still deplorable.

Let’s say I have a puppy but I can’t afford one at this stage in my life (lack of money is a common reason for wanting to abort). What do I do with this puppy?

Since it’s still small, I’m going to cram it in a blender while conscious and liquefy it to a bloody soup, disposing of the concoction in the trash.

That might work for a small puppy, but what about an older dog? It won’t fit in a blender.

How about this then: Without using anesthesia, I’m going to chop each of the dogs legs off, one by one, with a pair of bolt cutters. But the dog is still alive at this point, so the job isn’t over yet. Now, I’m going to pick up a giant rock, slam it down on the dog’s head to crush it, and then throw the dog’s mangled body in a bio hazard bag.

Do you think the methods of getting rid of the dog were disturbing? Who wouldn’t?

If I got caught getting rid of just one dog with either of the two described methods, not only would I be jailed because it’s illegal, my mug shot would be all over the internet accompanied by hateful epithets demanding my torturous death. In my defense, I could argue that it was my right and choice to kill my dog. I could say what I did to the dog was none of the government’s business.  I could say the dog was better off dead than leading a less-than-ideal life. However,  not one of those excuses would sway a single person.

But unfortunately, those two methods are basically the same used to kill thousands of fetuses every day.  Sound familiar? The first procedure I described was very similar to an aspiration abortion, commonly performed in the first trimester of pregnancy. Don’t believe me? Look it up, watch one. Its barbaric

How is an induction abortion performed?

Day 1: To help ensure the baby will be delivered dead and not alive, the abortionist uses a large needle to inject digoxin or potassium chloride through the woman’s abdomen or vagina, targeting the baby’s heart, torso, or head.

When the digoxin takes effect, the lethal dose causes a fatal cardiac arrest, and the baby’s life will end. (Even if the needle misses the baby, digoxin can still kill the baby when released into the amniotic sack, but will usually take longer to kill the child.)
​
During the same visit, the abortionist inserts multiple laminaria sticks, or sterilized seaweed, to open up the woman’s cervix.
​
Day 2: The abortionist replaces the laminaria and may perform a second ultrasound to ensure that the baby is dead. If the child is still alive, the abortionist administers a second lethal dose of digoxin or potassium chloride. During this visit, the abortionist may administer labor-inducing drugs
Week 9: By nine weeks LMP, the child can suck its thumb, open and close its jaw, stretch, and sigh. The baby’s teeth begin to form and the heart completes dividing into four chambers.

Week 8: At eight weeks LMP, the preborn baby’s hands and feet are developing, and the neural pathways in the baby’s brain start to form. The child is constantly moving in the uterus, although the mother cannot feel it.

Weeks 4-5: During this stage of pregnancy, the preborn child is developing rapidly. At four to five weeks LMP — that is, four to five weeks since the first day of the mother’s last period, and just two to three weeks following fertilization (conception) — the baby’s organs start to develop, and the heart begins to beat. These developmental milestones often take place before the mother even knows she is pregnant.

To prepare for a D&E abortion, the abortionist uses laminaria, a form of sterilized seaweed, to open the woman’s cervix 24 to 48 hours before the procedure. The laminaria soaks up liquid from the woman’s body and expands, widening (i.e., dilating) the cervix.
​
When the woman returns to the abortion clinic, the abortionist may administer anesthesia and further open the cervix using metal dilators and a speculum. The abortionist inserts a large suction catheter into the uterus and turns it on, emptying the amniotic fluid.

After the amniotic fluid is removed, the abortionist uses a sopher clamp — a grasping instrument with rows of sharp “teeth” — to grasp and pull the baby’s arms and legs, tearing the limbs from the child’s body. The abortionist continues to grasp intestines, spine, heart, lungs, and any other limbs or body parts. The most difficult part of the procedure is usually finding, grasping and crushing the baby’s head. After removing pieces of the child’s skull, the abortionist uses a curette to scrape the uterus and remove the placenta and any remaining parts of the baby.
 
The abortionist then collects all of the baby’s parts and reassembles them to make sure there are two arms, two legs, and that all of the pieces have been removed.

Around three weeks after conception the child has a heart that is pumping his own blood (frequently a different type than the mother’s).

By the ninth and tenth week, teeth and fingernails are growing, and the baby can turn his head and frown. He also hiccups, sucks his thumb, and reacts to loud noises. A week later he begins grasping objects placed in his hand and can smile.

My name is Cottee and I am 25 years old. Five months ago I had an abortion and it has completely ruined my life.

 

My husband and I were newly married when we carelessly fell pregnant. We panicked, as we didn't feel "ready" to be parents - even though my dream is to be a mother. My husband said that we should terminate the pregnancy and try again when the time was right. We sought abortion counselling from a family planning clinic and were also assured that the abortion would have no affect on my future fertility - as this was a huge concern of mine. I agreed to the abortion but I never felt convinced that I was making the right decision. I expressed this to my husband who simply told me that my fears were not justified and it would all be okay.

 

Immediately following the abortion I was overcome with regret. This manifested into depression and suicidal thoughts. Over the following months I started to deteriorate physically and mentally. I was having increasing pelvic pains and new that something wasn't right. Finally I found answers, after being brushed off by many doctors. And last month I had surgery which found that I was suffering from a pelvic infection (most likely caused by the abortion) and also riddled with endometriosis. I was told that my prospects for future fertility are limited.

 

I feel like my life is over and I just want to die. The grief and regret are eating me inside. I cannot live knowing that I had the chance to be a mother and I let it slip away. I hate myself. I hate my husband. And I hate my life. Every minute of every day I think about the abortion. My mind spins in circles thinking about how much I regret the past, how much I hate the present and how much I fear the future. The only thing that brings me comfort is knowing that at any moment, if it all becomes too much - I have the power to end my own suffering by taking my life.

 

Please help me. I don't know what to do.

The data suggest," observes Joseph Dellapenna, author of the most definitive work of U.S. abortion history, "that there have been as many maternal deaths in the United States annually from legal abortions (estimates range from 15 to 35 per year) as there were maternal deaths from illegal abortions in the years immediately before Roe v. Wade was decided."

Those who offer the unsafe abortion argument frequently appeal to examples outside of the United States. They point to some countries (such as many in Africa) that prohibit abortion and experience high maternal mortality rates and to other countries (such as most in Europe and North America) that permit abortion and boast low mortality. They infer from this correlation that laws against abortion cause a high incidence of maternal death. But that's a fallacy.

The highest-mortality nations are developing countries with poor maternal health care; the lowest-mortality nations are developed countries with advanced maternal health care. This is true irrespective of abortion policy. Some countries, for example, permit abortion and have high rates of mortality because their health care system is lacking. Other countries prohibit most abortions and have very low rates of maternal death (often lower than that of the U.S.). These countries include Chile, Ireland, Poland, Malta, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, and Lebanon.

I'm a 15 year old Pro-choice person trying to see both sides of the argument with this comment.

I have a couple reasons as to why I chose my path and I would really appreciate keeping religion out of the discussion as it can/will skew the results of your opinion. So let me explain how I see this from my point of view.

1." The Baby is a living person"
To me people consider a impregnated womb a living person. This confuses me however because yes it CAN turn into a human but to me it just isn't. Let me make an analogy to further elaborate my view. If you are an engineer creating machines and you create the outline of a phone(fertilized egg) which can further be grown and enhanced by fundings and aid from the company(Parent). Unfortunately though the comany can't fund the project anymore due to financial issues, the project is cut(Abortion). Now how does that relate to an abortion? Well, in my eyes the fertilized egg has POTENTIAL to be a functioning human being. You would consider a wheel a bike or a piece of paper a book; but as you add on and develope it, it becomes a fully developed item.

2. "The child has no say in the matter"

Now this reason is where is get controversial as it's extremely objective. To me though, i'm extremely practical so the overall population is more important than a potential life(Look to first reason as to why I sat potential). Bringing a whole new person into existence to a family unprepared and struggling only makes the childs life worse. Adoption doesn't work as about 100,000 kids are left unadopted each year leaving them to feel unwanted. This also adds one more person to the already over populated earth(may sound messed up but small amounts add up over time.) Lets say the parents keep the child? Well now the parentd are struggling to take care of a child and will probably lead to an abusive or at the very least stressful relationship.

3. Heres my last point just from a biological stand point. We have feelings and emotions and most people dont want to see a baby be killed. However why is this life so important. What universal reason justifies his/her existence? "We all deserve to live" is a common statement but thats your empathy talking because we all fear death. We all fear pain. Its confusing to me how people would let an unborn child be more valuable and protected when people die all around us. No one thinks about it, no one does anything. Soldiers, citizens, animals all killed with no say in the matter or chance. Its like they were "aborted". Why do so many people weigh a babie's life over others. Would you kill an unborn baby or Donald Trump. An umborn baby or Hitler. Most people would pick the unborn child but are blind or in to much denial to admit they were unborn children too. Would you abort them and why? Why would there value change because of their actions. Every view is objective and thats why im sharing mine to get an insight knowledge on how other people think. Thankyou for reading and please tell me your view so I can expand my knowledge and get to know your point of view.

Here's how it works.

Our individual DNA process is a continuous process, unfurling from the moment of conception. There is no later stage of our existence that is not dependent on earlier stages of our existence, as a continuous entity in space and time. Our DNA process is continuous in both space and time from the moment of our conception, to the moment of our death.

Acceptance, rationalization of the termination of an already unfurling DNA process, once invited to unfurl, requires the irrational acceptance of a temporal bias. In the continuum of space/time, that continuously unfurling DNA process is not a complete individual human 'yet.' That is because we are not regarding that human over the complete time-space continuum that it exists in. But, the only thing required to see the complete individual human is the passage of time.

We are of course much more than our unfurling DNA processes, but whatever we are, the basis of our life, cannot exist without the unmolested possession of that unfurling DNA process.

The fetus is a concrete example of a new individual DNA process, unfurling. There is and has been a conflict to define the most fundamental aspect of an individual -- the term of its existence. The resolution of this conflict -- between the newest individual and others -- is resolved by others, based on whatever philosophical or moral guidance they bring to the conflict. The rationalizations in support of abortion boil down to the convenience of the others, based mostly on a shaky temporal bias that is permitted to stand, unquestioned.

Abortion all hinges on whether we are talking about a living human being, not around a women’s right to choose. Many pro-choice people suggest inconsistent or non-science based qualifiers to determine whether someone is a human being deserving of the right to life, excluding already born human beings in some way. For example, saying it’s a life when it feels pain; when it is aware it is living; when it has a certain cognitive level; etc. There are people who have disorders or medical conditions to cause them not to feel pain, or not to have full cognitive capacity, or ‘sentience.’ There are people in comas. Can you kill someone just because they are unaware? What if they’re asleep? Etc. No matter what you say defines humanity has to include everyone or else it is inconsistent and a slippery slope. This is why pro-lifers agree life begins at conception. By the way, the heart starts beating around 21 days gestation, which is before women even get a positive pregnancy test. So if that is someone’s standard for a living person, then abortion still doesn’t make sense because you wouldn’t get an abortion if you have no clue you’re pregnant.

I can tell you about two incidences that really educated me on pre-born life...  The first was what happened to a baby bird when my neighbor's cruel son dashed it's egg on the concrete at my house....   I rushed to stop him, but I was too late, the tiny bird, fully formed, gasped for breathe & writhed for at least 5 minutes.  I was helpless to save the poor thing, so I just watched with sadness.  That was a forced evacuation but no scraping and suctioning or pulling involved......    Then the second, was once when I had chickens, I had apparently skipped an egg (from another day) in the nest box when I collected the eggs for the day.  How do I know this egg was sitting there for a while?  Because when I cracked it into the frying pan, I saw the chic moving in the yolk. I grabbed a spoon quick as I could to pull it out.  It was only has big as a 1/4 of an inch long, yet it's beak, feet, and eye were clearly visible and the body vigorously moved, the beak opening and closing. When it died, it melted into the yolk and was hardly visible except for the eye, which was black.  I felt sooooooo bad. Another forced evacuation, and I had been the cause of ending it's life, there was no way to put it back together.....  ..... These two incidences in my own life showed me without a doubt how marvelously formed pre-born or pre-hatched creatures are.... They are precious and alive...The same as a human pre-born is....... ... Personally, I am pro-life (and no, not in the way most pro-lifers are). If I had become pregnant by any means, I would carry the baby to full term and raise it (or give it to a loving family if I am not financially stable enough to keep a baby). Politically, however, I am Pro-Choice. I do not believe that the government should have a say in what women do with their pregnancies. I dislike this video for taking a side in the abortion discussion. Listen to the last line of the video: "access to legal abortions make women's life safer and healthier". It should say "access to SAFE abortions..." There's a difference, in my own opinion. If the abortion is made in a safe environment, then it can be argued that it is healthy. However, LEGALIZATION DOES NOT guarantee that this will happen. And here is where it might get interesting. The video mentions that in the US the risk of death associated with childbirth is higher than that of an abortion. But think outside the US. Think about underdeveloped countries. I speak of what I experience. Here, in Argentina, health is free, so you don't have to pay to get medical assistance. Nevertheless, you find hospitals in poor states, specialists missing (specially in pediatrics), and equipment not available to use due to lack of maintenance. Corruption, bad politics, you name it. So, now imagine, we are having this discussion of whether abortion should be legal or not in the middle of this health (and economical) crisis. How do you imagine abortions will be carried on if even when you are ill you receive poor or not a treatment at all? So this is why I say that legal abortion is not the same as a safe abortion. Legal is nice on paper, but does not guarantee a safe procedure. Furthermore, I would have wanted to know whether the embryo is considered a part of the human body or is inside it. Wouldn't that kind of information be interesting as well? I mean, whether the embryo has its own genetic code different from the pregnant woman or not? Of course no one would object to clipping nails; your own body, the nails have the same genetic code as the rest of your body, I suppose. But maybe I am wrong, so it would be interesting at least to see that information as well.  I excuse myself for any mistake in spelling or cohesion, but I'm not a native speaker of English.

Most people who are pro life often say that abortion is murder. However, murder is defined as the unlawful premeditated killing of one human being by another. Abortion isn’t murder because the fetus isn’t human yet. Now we have the argument of “When does a person become a person”. I believe that with sentience comes humanity. A fetus isn’t aware that it’s even alive until 24-28 weeks of gestation. Being killed before then and never being born are essentially the same thing to the fetus. Also, the fetus can’t feel pain until at least the 20 week mark.
Now putting the child up for adoption is another option, but it’s not that simple either. A healthy, white baby boy may be adopted within months, but the same cannot be said for ethnic or disabled babies. For example, the average child waits three years before its adopted, and the average age of a child awaiting adoption is right. So, adoption isn’t this perfect option either. And let’s face it there isn’t a black and white answer on whether abortion is right or not. A lot of the situations people are arguing over are very grey. There is never going to be the perfect option, so all you can do is choose what best fits the place that you’re in.

The intellectual dishonesty in this comment section is very troubling. We must all ask ourselves objectively "when does human life start?" If your answer is the viability point of survival outside the womb, then the counterargument is that as medicine improves babies can be kept safely alive (outside the womb) earlier and earlier and your point is invalid, the baby would now be independent of it's mother, often at 19 or 20 weeks of gestation. If you believe functioning brain waves are a marker for human life, then a person in a coma would now not be a person, that point is also invalid. If you believe the "fetus" has no feelings emotions etc, the same logic can be applied to a 1 day old newbody baby. All the arguments for "womens health" are logical fallacies nobody bothers to point out, the conversation isn't about women at all, it's about determining the exact point human life starts. It's a simply distinction that many don't understand. The new supreme court will likely look at the science of fetal development and understand this important point.

Double standards. If a pregnant woman is murdered it's considered a double homicide, but if a woman gets an abortion, it's just a fetus and not a "real" life. For everyone saying that it isn't double standards, read this article: https://supreme.findlaw.com/legal-commentary/is-killing-an-undiscovered-first-trimester-fetus-murder-in-california.html

Here's a quote from that article for those of you who don't feel like reading too much of it anyway: "In response to the ruling in Keeler, the California legislature amended its murder statute to add "fetus" to the class of victims whose malicious killing would qualify as murder, coupled with an exception for consensual abortions."

"... would qualify as murder, coupled with an exception for consensual abortions." How the heck is that not a double standard? Granted, that is just in California and I'm not sure what other states' laws are about this subject, but the point is humans decide whether a fetus' life being terminated counts as murder or as a "perfectly fine choice" based off of the convenience of the people involved, and the mother's consent to the fetus being terminated. illegal, should we simply make those legal too? The 8th amendment
guarantees rights and protects the value of the unborn unconditionally. If you are given the gift of a baby, you should treasure that gift.

I don't like the idea of killing a developing human, but because some mothers will otherwise resort to dangerously unprofessional abortions, I'm partially pro-choice. In my opinion, abortions should be allowed only until maybe seven weeks after conception. That means that the embryo is not yet a fetus, it is only just starting to get a heartbeat and develop all of its organs, and it is nowhere near ready to leave the womb. Still, it should be enough time for the decision about getting an abortion to be made.

Eventually, though, we have to call a human a human. Even though passing out of the womb is a huge milestone, premature births happen all the time, and yet those are still humans, not "clusters of cells." Human development is still taking place, and by the time the classification moves from "embryo" to "fetus," the foundations for the entire human body are already laid.

While any number of weeks is arbitrary, it's important that we set a limit on when living things who will otherwise one day become members of our societies can be killed just because their mothers don't want them. After all, despite currently living inside their mothers, they have their own combination of DNA, their own behaviors inside the womb, and their own bodies. One doesn't have an abortion the same way one amputates a limb. A separate human life is at stake, and that's what most pro-choice advocates need to consider before just saying, "It's the woman's choice."

As per usual there is a ton of scientific misinformation in this comment section...on both sides of the debate.  Thought I’d add this to the discussion. The reason why abortion is usually talked about in the context of “before 20 weeks” isn’t because the fetus is “a clump of cells,” or anything to do with pain.  It’s because before 22 weeks gestation a fetus is incapable of surviving without the mother. If a preterm fetus is born before or at 22 weeks, doctors do not have a legal obligation to try life saving procedures (cpr, intubation, etc) and they don’t attempt those procedures because that baby is not capable of surviving. At 23-25 weeks a discussion with the parents needs to be had about their wishes for neonatal resuscitation and after 25 weeks there is usually a legal obligation to try as there is more data to support that those 25+ have viable survival rates. A fetus aborted before 20 weeks has no chance of being viable outside of the womb at that gestational age. If that pregnancy had continued, then certainly they could have (though 15% of all pregnancies end in spontaneous first trimester miscarriage). Abortion often means you’re ending the potential for a life, and people will fall on different sides of that moral question. But legally, you do not have the right to force a women to get an abortion, or not get an abortion. Autonomy gives us all the legal right to control our own body’s medical care.

A useful rundown of the procedures, although I had to pause at "fetal and placental tissue is removed" and go look up what these fetuses look like at those ages... because humans like to categorize whole groups of living human beings as "okay to harm/kill" via dehumanization, and calling it "fetal tissue" instead of "parts of the fetus" or "parts of the baby" struck me as possibly along those lines.

However, it turns out that 21 weeks is pretty much the barrier for life outside the womb; if the fetus has not gotten to 22 weeks' development, it pretty much can't survive. (Though, it still looks very much like a baby, not just a blob of flesh, even as early as 12 weeks.) So this avoids one of the biggest problems I have with the pro-abortion movement: "Failed" abortions that literally leave a living child to just die on a table or in a garbage can (this is a thing that happens, even in the United States, but I'm not sure how widespread it is).

Anyway, the methods mentioned that take place before 22 weeks' growth are definitely not killing a baby who could survive right then. Which is different from the later abortions, especially D&X, which deliberately kills a baby who could survive outside the womb -- and the argument of "severe birth defects" is one that is up for debate. I've heard that a lot of disabled people are upset at the mindset that a disabled child (of any level of severity) ought to be deliberately killed rather than allowed to live, and I'm rather of the opinion that people who have lived their lives with these problems are in a better position to judge the ethics of this act than I am.

Even the kid who was born without arms or legs has gone on to have a good life and be a motivational speaker ("If this didn't stop me from doing good things with my life, what's stopping *you*?"). I know a man with hydrocephalus who's got a bit of processing problems, a bit of trouble with his balance, but he's lived a good long life and been encouraging to many people around him. And look at how many people are convinced that it's okay to kill a fetus simply for having Down Syndrome! What an insult to all those wonderful people in the world who have Down Syndrome and still brighten the lives of those around them, or even achieve college degrees! "It would be better for you if you never lived! Because you're different from other people!"

That being said... I acknowledge that there are certainly times when the mother's life is at stake, and that not having abortion facilities available can lead to avoidable deaths. And I acknowledge that there may be cases where the fetus has the kind of birth defect where they wouldn't survive pregnancy enough to live outside the womb. There are legitimate reasons for abortion, and an outright ban would be unethical.

What's funny for me is, I've examined the issue from two perspectives: the perspective according to my religious viewpoint, and the perspective if you set aside all religious ideas in my head and just try to analyze it from a secular viewpoint. And according to my religion: There's nothing fundamentally wrong with abortion! You're not killing a baby. God creates the human soul at the point of the first breath, so as long as you kill the body before that breath happens, there was never a person.

(Though, again, the "it's not even a baby" mindset leads to situations where the "failed" abortion (and live baby outside the mom), who ought to have rights at that point, is left to die, or hurt/harmed. And it leads to the Barbara Boxer mindset, where it's impossible to agree that a live-born baby should be afforded 100% of the human rights the rest of us get, regardless of if the mom was in there for an abortion or not. And there's a bit of sadness over the loss of a potential life, but that's not enough to base policy on.)

However, from the secular perspective: There is absolutely nothing that distinctly separates a fetus from a baby. From the moment of conception, that thing has its own DNA, and it is alive, and it is human and nothing else. You can say "it's okay to kill a living human being before the human is capable of surviving outside the womb" if you like, and I'm not sure I would disagree, but you can't say "that's not a human being" or "that's not alive" or "that's just part of the mother's body" because all those statements are false. Without the human soul, the baby inside the womb and the baby outside the womb are the same baby, just one is breathing air finally. And if you use the D&X procedure past the 21-week threshold, you are killing a baby who could survive outside the womb (even if for a little bit, but possibly for a normal if handicapped life) -- there's no distinction there, you're killing a living human being who, if you did the procedure a little differently, would be considered to be fully human by our courts of law and by the public in general.

Also, people who say that the difference between a 22-week-old fetus and a baby is that the fetus can't survive without intervention... well, there's living babies, premies, who can't survive without intervention, and they still have human rights and should not be killed. And if you say it's a difference of how aware they are, well, a newborn isn't as aware as a toddler, yet we can't just kill a newborn. The only real distinction between a fetus and a baby is that the baby can get handed off to another person, leaving the mom to go her way, while the fetus can't (for a while).

So I do find it kinda bizarre that from a Christian perspective, abortion is no big deal, but from a secular perspective, we really ought to have better controls over it -- better legal standards to ensure that no human being gets killed when it could survive.

Considerations for the issue of Abortion:

1. At the moment of conception the fetus "is" human by it's DNA. But does that make it a "person?" What is a person?

2. Even if we suppose a fetus is a person, does that supposed person have a right to your body?

3. Thought Experiment (based on the previous question):

If a homeless man had his vital organs hooked up to your own to keep him alive, and you agreed to it for 9 months to heal him, do you retain the right to revoke access to your body at any time? Does the homeless man now have a right to your body, regardless of your future desires? If you separate his access to your body and he dies, are you responsible for his death, or was his body's inability to fully function on its own responsible?

4. What are the positive and negative consequences to allowing abortion vs banning it? Who is impacted by the decision? Whose rights are being violated?

5. What limits, if any, should be placed on abortions and what are the circumstances?

Abortion is still a live debate. People try to make it simple, but it's not. Currently, I think the answers are out there, most of us just aren't wise enough to see them. I have my own opinion on this, but feel free to respond with your thoughts.

I have always supported abortions. Ever since I was little I saw the matter as obvious and deemed the pro-life as radicals (growing up in Sweden, where pretty much everyone supports a family's right to abortion).

However, as I have grown older and gotten an education, I see no other way but to percieve abortions of fetuses (or really, any human zygote) as immensly immoral. When does a foetus become a human being? Obviously, this is a hard question to answer since there is no real definition to it, and even if there were, it would in the end be subjective and not based on reality. That being said, it does not really matter when we consider the human being to have been developed, since that does not really say anything at all about the factual, essential existence of the living organism. Therefore, I see no option but to view the unborn as a human being since its first conception and its early stages in prenatal development. A bundle of tissue or not, the organism possesses its own DNA, its own genome, independently from its mother. Therefore, it is not a part of the mother, but an independent (in this sense) human being with human rights. Of course, morals are highly subjective, but in a world of subjectiveness, we can take german philosopher Immanuel Kant's categorical imperative as a path to what "can be perceived" as ethically correct. If you do not know this imperative, it is basically the notion that the only way one should act is a way that one would want to see being an universal law. This is also pretty much the essence of the Golden Rule as well.

Taking Kant into account, his imperative states that morality is a maxim that one would like to see becoming a universal law. I believe that we all could agree that murder is nothing we would want to see becoming a universal law, and therefore it has to be immoral. Therefore, abortion is immoral.

But of course, ethics is incredibly subjective and there is, of course, no correct answer in moral problems (which for example Friedrich Nietzche explores as well as the entire "school" of Nihilism).

The Greek Orthodox view on Abortion
The Sixth Commandment (Thou Shalt not Kill)
One of the most widely disseminated arguments in favor of performing abortions is that each woman has the right to control the functions of her body, in whatever way she finds necessary, right up to terminating the life of an unwanted fetus. The Greek Orthodox Church rejects this argument outright. First of all, the Church points to the sacredness of a God-given life, and also points to the fact that if it is forbidden for a Christian to raise his hand against his own life, all the more so does a Christian not have the right to terminate the life of another, even if this life has the appearance of a still not completely formed embryo. Our body is the temple of the Holy Spirit, as the Apostle Paul teaches; this means that the cessation of the life of any other person is considered to be a crime not only in regard to that person, but likewise in regard to the Holy Spirit.
The Holy Fathers teach that a fetus is a complete PERSON ~body and soul~ created the moment of conception and that all those PERSONS (embryos) that were killed before coming into this world in this criminal away WILL ASK FROM GOD (at His Second Coming) to RENDER HIS JUSTICE UPON THOSE WHO TOOK THEIR LIFE (parents and doctors) … ON THEIR BEHALF for their personal pain and desolation.

I have mixed feelings about abortions. I am Pro-Choice, but I hate how the stance is always tied into feminism. In America, "A Woman's Choice!" is what many liberals say, but I think that its unnecessary to always emphasize women. Technically, men don't get pregnant in the first place, but I feel like the phrase is trying so hard to make it seem like America is a sexist country or that the country is non-progressive.
Anyways, I know that women may do their own "DIY" abortions that will most likely be unsafe and may end up killing the mother and that the finical/health/support risks may be too high. I'd also like to point out: In many countries where rape is more prominent and also unsafe, pregnancies may result and I think it would be so cruel to deny someone an abortion when it was not remotely their fault (especially if they are a minor, good god!) The biggest issue is overpopulation. We can't afford to support more births that we already have! ( I really stress that last one?)
On the other side, I do understand the Pro-Life(rs?) view. How is life defined? Does it necessarily start when a brain, a beating heart, and other organs start working? If fetuses aren't alive, are they dead? How do we humans get to choose what life is defined as?
Also, I know some women regret doing abortions because they would have loved to have a child at that time and they feel like they missed a wonderful opportunity. Finally, there's also the issue of selective abortions. In China, the one-child policy resulted in parents choosing to abort females to prevent a life without a son, which could mean that they won't receive care in their old age. That doesn't really seem fair, does it?
I've started to come to this insane conclusion: Perhaps we are killing life, but maybe all the cons outweigh the pros, and in order to save our planet and the human life on it, we have to say goodbye to some of our young. It's like euthanasia. I'd love it if abortions could somehow be prohibited if they are gender or genetically (ex: down syndrome babies) selected. It may be almost impossible to do that. If we can change the role that gender plays in some countries, perhaps people won't selectively abort. If we can change the attitude around down syndrome babies, perhaps parents won't selectively abort.

I’m kind of in between pro life and pro choice. It’s true that cases of rape, incest, and medical deformities/risks make up less than 1% of abortions, but at the same time, it’s been proven time and time again that outlawing abortion causes more problems than it starts. I think everyone can agree that abortion isn’t a “good” thing. I also think that the government should not have control over an issue like this, but at the same time, I can see the reasoning on the other side. Personally, the issue for me is, once the baby (or fetus, whatever you want to call it) has all of its vital organs, it can feel things. It has a beating heart and working brain. Bringing harm to a human life form in the later stages of development, in my opinion, is in humane. It’s such a complex issue that I wish we had a better alternative to.

The city (itself) seems to be waiting almost 'eagerly' for any capable 'community of humans' to come to fill the town and live there. This would likely grant the people a rich life and provide a healthy environment for the tribe to proliferate. The tribe wants to reach the city, but they must cross the deep lake to reach the other side. They can also sense that they must have a healthy culture for the city (itself) to accept their presence. The tribal elders are huddled around the bonfire, staring at the stars and "talking to the city." The city tells them they must "bring a healthy race of people." They must decide whether it would be wiser to fashion ships and Roe across the lake or would it 'fit their fancy' to Wade across? The city warns them: "Be careful what you ask for!" Some were saying that there was 'treasure to be discovered' along the bottom of the lake and that they would mine it. Soon after they embarked and entered the lake, a steady attrition was steadily taking effect - but it was often said that "sacrifices have to be made on this journey." No one noticed the effects of attrition, as it had (at an earlier time) been "priced in." Eventually the tribal chief reached the other side but when he got there he looked around to discover that everyone else had drowned or had passed away from the Storm.
He had emerged from the lake and was destined to be crowned as the "King" of a shining city of NOTHING.

Although I don't think we should expect that every issue is resolvable, it doesn't help in the case of abortion that we've made it an issue of sociology, gender equality, choice, etc., when in fact the issue is philosophical: what exactly is the status of the fetus, and what kind of ethical consideration, if any, do we owe to the fetus? This is the entire question, with the other questions entering only secondarily. So, for example, if it turned out that the fetus were fully human, not some non-human or intermediate species; were genetically distinct and not a part of other organisms but a whole unto itself, though essentially dependent; were undeveloped though actively developing according to its own internal instructions, only ever becoming a fully-formed human being like you and me -- and the only thing from which fully-formed human beings like you and me have ever come; and were distinguishable from fully-formed human beings like you and me only in virtue of factors that are ethically irrelevant, such as size, location (within the body of another), specific functionality of individual systems, and so on; then it would seem that a woman's choice is totally irrelevant, in the same way that no where else does a person's right to choose trump the fundamental right of another -- quite the contrary, in fact, with infringement of fundamental rights of others being precisely where the line is drawn in limiting choice: you can choose to do anything you want so long as your choice doesn't unduly or disproportionately pose harm to another. If it turned out that the status were highly ambiguous or indeterminate, yet without recommending (above all) caution or the Hippocratic principle, then choice might enter as a sort of tiebreaker or to tip the scales. The idea is that it is always secondary, following upon the question of fetal status.

Here I've made a shortened version of the argument that a fetus deserves at least some ethical consideration, though not necessarily to the same degree as you and me; but that wasn't my main point. The main point is that the status of the fetus is all that matters when the action in question involves cutting the thing to pieces, and to talk about choice before settling the question of status is to blabber solipsistically about something of little relevance. Both sides of the argument would be better off if we kept the focus squarely on the question of fetal rights (again, whether or not they have any), and if ever we could hope to rationally resolve the issue of abortion it would be in this way.

While I actually enjoyed the video and did learn something from it, I do have a slight problem with it.  You clearly have a bias towards one opinion/side and present facts, images and pathos that support that side.  There's nothing wrong with making a video explaining/advocating for legal abortion.  But, this is a (presumably non-partisan) science channel and would probably be best served by dealing strictly in fact (i.e. presenting both facts that could be used to argue for and against abortion) and not allowing personal bias to slip (jump?) through.  If you want to make a video that explains why you support legal abortion, then present the video as such (i.e. come right out and state that the video is your opinion).  I genuinely wanted to learn how an abortion works; I wasn't looking for selectively chosen facts, images and pathos to make a not-so-subtle political statement.

Wonderful video put out by ASAPScience, providing facts on the different procedures used in abortions. Although I would love to talk about these surgeries, I believe I would be repeating this fantastic video. So instead, I will be discussing the medical ethics behind having an abortion. These moral arguments are the baseline for political arguments, but in no way do I mean to be political with this comment.

As a future healthcare provider, it is my duty to protect my patients. As a Utilitarian thinker, it is my duty to provide the greatest good for the greatest number of people. I believe that granting women the right to choose to have an abortion will fulfill both of these tasks. There are several cases where the life of the mother is in jeopardy, or that the quality of the proposed child's life would be hindered. However, there are some cases where none of these factors come into play when making the decision to get an abortion. These cases are simply a choice made by the mother of the fetus to terminate its birth. Although some people would argue that this is an unjustifiable case of abortion, my medical ethics tends to disagree.

As a health professional, the most important thing you can choose to respect about your patients is their autonomy. Autonomy is defined as the freedom from external control. As healthcare providers, we may try and persuade our patients to make decisions that we believe are right for them, but must respect their decisions about their life. If healthcare professionals, experts in the field of medicine and care, know enough to respect decisions made about abortions and other medical choices, then why should our politicians and lawmakers feel the need to disrespect autonomy in this case?

Although I respect other's decisions and beliefs, depending on the situation and certain exceptions, I do not support the idea of abortion. The act of abortion may be an understandable choice in circumstances that involve serious harm to the mother due to health related reasons, or the child has been conceived through the act of rape. However, many abortions take place because it is seen as an inconvenience to the mother or father. Mothers or those that support abortion use the popular argument of "their body, their choice", but this defies science. Pregnancy involves two bodies, not just one. The embryo is not an organ, it is a growing life. From the moment the baby is conceived it forms its own DNA. The child is in the mother's body, but it is not a part of the mother's body, therefore is a completely separate human being. Along with this argument, many choose to believe that a woman has the right to control her own body, but if that statement is true, then they also have the responsibility to do so before they get pregnant. If a woman knows they do not want a child, then it is their responsibility to practice abstinence, use protection, or invest in a reliable birth control. An abortion is not a simple medical procedure that should be seen as an easy avoidance of parenthood. Abortion results in death 100% of the time.

Concerning this Video:

If AsapSCIENCE really cared about a woman's right to choose, they would provide actual information to empower women to make a choice.

Someone contemplating an abortion does not want a sanitized explanation using vague medical terminology. They want to know what actually happens during the procedure, what it feels like, and what to expect.

They may want to know what the removed "uterus contents" will look like at a certain stage of their pregnancy, and weather they will be allowed to look at it if they choose.

They may want to know how they will feel after the procedure and during their recovery.

I once visited an abortion provider's website, and it was more honest and informative than this video. The various abortion procedures I read about were very invasive. And they do not put the woman under- she is awake and alert, and participates in the process (at least for the later-term abortions) even as someone would who is giving birth.

I imagine, from reading, that it would be a traumatic experience to have gone though. The abortion provider's website tended to agree that this might be the case for some woman, and offered the advice: go home, watch TV, and try not to think about it. (I am not making this up).

If you are considering an abortion. Please don't do it. You may not want to be in the position to have to choose, but choose you must. Do not let politics, family, or stigma pressure you into doing something you don't want to. Choose what is right for you AND your baby. Choose life.

What a deceptive video.

When describing an abortion at 16 weeks the video fails to describe the characteristics of the pregnancy.

At 16 weeks the fetus is no longer an amalgamation of cells. At sixteen weeks the fetus is plainly recognizable as a human being. Any individual who viewed the child would see that it had arms, legs, buttocks, and unique facial structure.

When a dialation and curettage abortion is performed a curette (typically hook shaped. The producer of this video used a currette that looks like a tongue scraper in an effort to make viewers think that material was being merely sluffed off the uterine walls)
In reality a hooked curette ensnared one of the child's body parts at random and the the doctor rips said limb from the child's body and pulls it back out through the cervix. When this procedure is completed the childs head is still typically intact and the internal organs are pushed out through the childs torn skin.

The producer of this video was plainly wrong when saying a dilation and evacuation would be performed after a dilation and curettage on. When and dilation and evacuation is performed a doctor uses a forceps to crush the child and then uses a sort of vacuum to suck out the child's pulverized remains.

Just FYI. When you read about the week an embryo develops something, those weeks begin the day of woman's last period. Meaning an embryo that is five weeks means, three weeks after ovulation, 1 week after missed period, but 5 weeks after the date of a woman's  last period. And that is how doctors date an embryo. So when most women find out they are pregnant they are already 5 to 6 weeks into a pregnancy as that is the week after they have fully missed a period. The embryo in fact has a heartbeat and the brain and spinal system is in place as well when a woman figures out she is pregnant. We heard here how many women die from trying to get an abortion done in secret in a non-professional setting, and that is most likely because of the pressure/laws against abortion pushing them to these unprofessional, unscrupulous individuals that the women feel they have to turn to because these unprofessional individuals will do it when most others can't or won't. Fetuses are uniquely different from born human beings in major ways, which casts doubt on the claim that they can be classified as human beings. The most fundamental difference is that a fetus is totally dependent on a woman's body to survive. Anti-choicers might argue that born human beings can be entirely dependent on other people too, but the crucial difference is that they are not dependent on one, specific person to the exclusion of all others. Anybody can take care of a newborn infant (or disabled person), but only that pregnant woman can nurture her fetus. She can’t hire someone else to do it.

The video claims: “In the U.S., the risk of death associated with childbirth is fourteen times higher in women than that of an abortion.” This comes from CDC data, and unfortunately, the CDC’s abortion data is woefully incomplete. Reporting is not mandatory, and California, which accounts for a significant percentage of abortions, does not report its abortion data to the CDC.

More importantly, the CDC itself has stated that its abortion mortality rate and maternal mortality rate are not comparable:

The maternal mortality rate is computed as all maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. In contrast, the measure used for abortion is a case-fatality rate which is computed per 100,000 legal abortions. These measures are conceptually different and used for different public health purposes.
“All maternal deaths” is defined as “the death of a woman while pregnant or within 1 year of pregnancy termination–regardless of the duration or site of the pregnancy–from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management.” It includes deaths related to births, miscarriages, ectopic pregnancies, and abortions. It is not a pure measure of deaths from childbirth.

Understanding rhetoric in media is important with a video such as this. Often the bias of a source is very clear in the presentation and editing of information. The actual information is pretty much secondary, because it's been edited down to a point that it only makes one side of an argument without effectively dealing with obvious counter-arguments. This lends an unwarranted level of credibility to a source. To someone who is familiar with this issue, the obvious omissions and obfuscations presented in this video are obvious, but to the uninformed or those already in the presenter's camp, it may not be so clear. I will endeavor to point out the most obvious example of rhetoric in this piece and let others decide whether or not it's enough to erode trust in the source: On late term abortions we're told WHY (they only reasoning for late abortions they give is fetal anomalies) they tend to be performed but not HOW. Ostensibly the video is, "What actually happens when you have an abortion?," but neither the procedure of late term abortions nor the experience of a woman undergoing the procedure is even discussed. But with the earlier term abortions, the opposite tactic is taken. The video discusses HOW they are performed (while glossing over such elements as what a curette does to both the uteran lining and the developing fetus, which would likely be distasteful) but not WHY they tend to be performed. Now that is a very significant change in one's argumentation! But why would one make such a switch? Well, the most obvious answer would seem to be to avoid the elements that are not in favor of a pro-abortion argument. In earlier abortions, the procedure is, seemingly, simpler, less violent. A pill or suction removes a small embryo or fetus (here illustrated by a simple, impersonal circle). These abortions tend to be performed more for choices that could be boiled down to "convenience." So the WHY is seemingly more distasteful than the HOW (particularly when the how is somewhat sanitized by the art and commentary). In the later cases, we're given only one WHY--severe fetal deformity--as the only statistically significant reason why late abortions occur. We are not given those statistics (or what constitutes "severe...deformity") but we're given that WHY and then moved on to why it's good for abortion to be illegal without even a passing mention of the HOW (which often involves partially delivering an almost full-term baby breach, cutting open its head and suctioning its brain matter). Obviously, the HOW is the more distasteful element here. Additionally, we're told of deaths from unsafe abortions, and the assumption is made that these only occur when the abortion is illegal. Google the name "Kermit Gosnell" and the many women who died in his completely legal and regulated abortion clinic, and you'll see that this is not entirely true. Now, I don't claim to be unbiased in this matter. But clearly AsapSCIENCE is not either. Nor are they "scientific" in their presentation of the facts, since they've only presented the elements that make their argument stronger. You don't have to agree with me or them, but I trust that this overlong post has demonstrated that using the word "SCIENCE" in your name (even in all caps) does not mean that you are honest with the facts of an issue.

Fertilization is a sequence of events that begins with the contact of a sperm (spermatozoon) with a secondary oocyte (ovum) and ends with the fusion of their pronuclei (the haploid nuclei of the sperm and ovum) and the mingling of their chromosomes to form a new cell. This fertilized ovum, known as a zygote, is a large diploid cell that is the beginning, or primordium, of a human being.
(Moore, Keith L. Essentials of Human Embryology. Toronto: B.C. Decker Inc, 1988, p.2)

The development of a human being begins with fertilization, a process by which two highly specialized cells, the spermatozoon from the male and the oocyte from the female, unite to give rise to a new organism, the zygote.
[Langman, Jan. Medical Embryology. 3rd edition. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1975, p. 3]

Zygote. This cell, formed by the union of an ovum and a sperm (Gr. zyg tos, yoked together), represents the beginning of a human being. The common expression ‘fertilized ovum’ refers to the zygote.
[Moore, Keith L. and Persaud, T.V.N. Before We Are Born: Essentials of Embryology and Birth Defects. 4th edition. Philadelphia: W.B. Saunders Company, 1993, p. 1]

I know this will be too difficult for some to understand, but just food for thought:

Let's say there were only a few people left, literally just a few, and I dunno maybe you were on board some spacecraft or something, or maybe there was some huge event on earth that wiped a lot of people out, whatever. One of you is pregnant though, conditions under which the conception took place are irrelevant, just that one of you is pregnant. As a presupposition, we're saying it's a given that our species wants to survive. At the end of the gestation period, what will come out (would this product add to your population in number)? If so, at what point during the process of gestation would it have been vital to allow it to grow? Then we'll add that a majority of those alive deem the process to be crucial if numbers are to increase, and therefore any attempt to destroy that growth might be seen as an act of sabotage. If one were to argue say, that currently there are too many people, thus justifying the destruction of our species to an extent, it then becomes a moral argument and that person is fine with genocide. The argument that the growing organism is merely a sack of cells (or some other simian phrase), is of course completely nonsensical given the outcome, and not even justifiable as a reason to destroy a possible benefit to the sum; e.g. "we decided not to continue the species because they start out as mere sacks of cells." The argument that the organism was imposed on an unwilling carrier, and therefore it's destruction is justified, is for the reasons mentioned above not connected to a crime having taken place, as it does not negate the end result of the process, or even alter it in any way; to equate the tragedy of crime or convenience with the process and therefore the termination thereof is then no different than killing a store employee because his store was robbed.

Where we are at currently, is that philosophical line in the sand between a people, and it's enemy. Relativism has had such an effect on so many individuals, that they are no longer able to understand even the most basic logic. People who stand in favor of the destruction of that "sack of cells" have now only one of two possible identities: first that they have knowingly chosen to join the ranks of evil, and second that any notion of morality must cease to impress them and they have become willfully silent, thereby giving consent to the ranks of evil. I promise, we will see some bizarre things in the coming years as a direct result of this type of thinking. As an immediate example, this statement I've made will either be 'tldr', or met with all manner of convoluted justification, incomplete/incoherent thoughts, etc.. BUT, I think some of you will easily understand it, those who wish harm on you however, will not.

Forgetting all of the emotion, I'd like people who are 'pro-choice' to clarify something for me. What exactly is it about the "facts" that we 'pro-lifers' so strongly disagree with? Obviously we accept that nature itself takes certain courses which we may not understand, but, to my mind, it is the intervention we have a problem with. My primary disagreement is that if it's alright to intervene in the future life of a child (emphasis on the future part), why is it not alright to intervene in the present life of an adult? After all, most murders occur for the same reason one might have an abortion. Practicality. You don't want somebody around and it seems, often, that the best course of action is to get rid of them. I think the problem we have is that you think of time and existence as some sort of linear process which is divided up into little sections, rather than as existence as a whole which has no particular time constraint, simply different happenings within a non-linear event. Two of those happenings are life and death, obviously, but there are hundreds of religions and philosophies which do not treat those two events as part of a linear sequence. And it seems, in regards to murder, most of you feel that you ought to let a persons life play out at least until the next happening. Why is that the case? Why, if you view it as non-linear, not condone murder as well?

This video does NOT at all explain what actually happens during a surgical abortion. After the cervix dilated, the baby's limbs are violently ripped off their body and pulled out, then the fetus's body is ripped off the head and pulled out, then the head is removed which is the hardest part of the operation. In order to remove the head of the baby, the doctors must first find it and crush it in order to reduce size. Once the doctors see a white liquid oozing out of the vagina, they know they have crushed it as this is the baby's brain. The remainder of the head is then pulled out and the abortion is complete. According to a Harvard study, an unborn baby can feel pain as early as 8 weeks meaning many of theses babies can FEEL their limbs getting ripped off. For everyone who thinks that abortion is simply the removal of a blob of cells, this is also untrue. Babies begin to take human form at 5 weeks of pregnancy and most abortions occur between 7-9 weeks (which means yes most aborted babies feel pain). Please take the time to actually educated your self before taking a pro-choice stance, adoption is always an option.
